section-content-text: This Act may be called the Commercial Courts Act, 2015. It extends to the whole of India. It shall be deemed to have come into force on the 23rd day of October, 2015., Chapter I, Section 1 of the Commercial Courts Act, 2015 does not specify the types of cases that come under the Act. Instead, it establishes the fundamental provisions regarding the title, extent, and commencement of the Act.

The Commercial Appellate Courts designated under section 3A, The Commercial Appellate Division in a High Court constituted under sub-section (1) of section 5., The Commercial Court constituted under sub-section (1) of section 3., A dispute arising out of ordinary transactions of merchants, bankers, financiers, traders, and other commercial matters including but not limited to: mercantile documents, export/import of merchandise or services, admiralty and maritime law, aircraft and equipment, carriage of goods, construction contracts, intellectual property rights, etc., The Commercial Division in a High Court constituted under sub-section (1) of section 4., Shall have the same meaning as assigned to it in clause (a) of article 236 of the Constitution of India., Any matter expressed or described upon any substance by means of letters, figures, marks, or electronic means intended to be used for recording that matter., A notification published in the Official Gazette, and the expression 'notify' shall be construed accordingly., The Schedule appended to the Act., The value of the subject matter in respect of a suit as determined under section 12, which shall not be less than three lakh rupees or such higher value as may be notified by the Central Government.

chapter-title: Constitution of Commercial Courts, Commercial Divisions, and Commercial Appellate Divisions
section-content-text: The State Government, after consultation with the concerned High Court, may constitute Commercial Courts at the district level. The State Government may specify the pecuniary value for such courts.

chapter-title: Constitution of Commercial Courts, Commercial Divisions, and Commercial Appellate Divisions
section-content-text: The State Government may designate Commercial Appellate Courts at the District Judge level.

chapter-title: Constitution of Commercial Courts, Commercial Divisions, and Commercial Appellate Divisions
section-content-text: The Chief Justice of the High Court may constitute Commercial Divisions in High Courts having ordinary original civil jurisdiction.

chapter-title: Constitution of Commercial Courts, Commercial Divisions, and Commercial Appellate Divisions
section-content-text: The Chief Justice of the High Court may constitute Commercial Appellate Divisions in High Courts.

chapter-title: Constitution of Commercial Courts, Commercial Divisions, and Commercial Appellate Divisions
section-content-text: The Commercial Court shall have jurisdiction over commercial disputes of Specified Value.

chapter-title: Constitution of Commercial Courts, Commercial Divisions, and Commercial Appellate Divisions
section-content-text: All suits and applications relating to commercial disputes of a Specified Value filed in a High Court shall be heard by the Commercial Division.

chapter-title: Constitution of Commercial Courts, Commercial Divisions, and Commercial Appellate Divisions
section-content-text: No civil revision application or petition shall be entertained against any interlocutory order of a Commercial Court.

chapter-title: Constitution of Commercial Courts, Commercial Divisions, and Commercial Appellate Divisions
section-content-text: Commercial Courts shall have jurisdiction over arbitration matters involving commercial disputes of Specified Value.
Specified Value shall be determined based on the relief sought in the suit or application. This includes recovery of money, market value of property, and other intangible rights.
A suit that does not require urgent interim relief shall not be instituted unless pre-institution mediation has been exhausted.
Appeals may be made to the Commercial Appellate Court or Commercial Appellate Division of the High Court.
Appeals should be disposed of within six months from the date of filing.
All pending suits of Specified Value in civil courts shall be transferred to Commercial Courts.

chapter-title: Amendments to the Provisions of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908
section-content-text: Provisions of the CPC shall stand amended in their application to suits in respect of commercial disputes.
Statistical data regarding suits and applications filed and disposed of by Commercial Courts shall be maintained and published.
The High Court may issue practice directions to supplement the provisions of this Act.
The State Government shall provide necessary infrastructure to facilitate the working of Commercial Courts.
The State Government may establish facilities for the training of Judges appointed to Commercial Courts.
The provisions of this Act shall have an overriding effect notwithstanding anything inconsistent with any other law.
The Central Government may make rules for carrying out the provisions of this Act.
The Central Government may make provisions to remove difficulties in giving effect to the Act.
The Commercial Courts Ordinance, 2015 is hereby repealed.
